p.hi: the cotton trade — running the blockade — Brisk Insurance business — interesting facts about the fire, &c.

div4.p:
I was astonished to-day in walking around the wharves to see what a large business is going on in the cotton trade.
I met with planters who were selling their crops for 8½ cents per pound.
Everything presented a lively aspect.
"Is not there a blockade?" I found myself involuntarily inquiring of the dray drivers that were hauling up immense loads.
"It don't matter," they replied, "about the blockade, cotton will go. " I looked upon a noble vessel which came in a day or two ago. A firm here made $40,000 on a cargo recently received.

Insurance companies are being organized, and every dollar's worth of property is being covered with a policy.
Never was there a finer field for making money by such companies.

I had a conversation to-day with Hon. Charles McBeth, Mayor of this city.
He says that history presents no parallel to the sympathy which is being manifested in behalf of this city.
His Excellency and his private secretary find it impossible to reply to one-half of the letters which contain remittances, so that resort is had to the city papers, through which to acknowledge the donations.
Georgia has given one-half of all that has been contributed thus far. The Mayor remarked to me, "I passed through the fire and all its scenes of sorrow without shedding a tear; but, sir, often times on opening these letters, all filled with sympathy and love, I have had my heart so moved as to be compelled to weep."

I have spent a delightful week in Charleston, at the Mills House, an excellent hotel, and now I am about to leave for Savannah, from which place you will hear from me; and as I claim to be a more "reliable" informant than some who patronize the press, you may not expect many "sensation" letters.

div3.head:
[for the Richmond Dispatch.]
the volunteer question.
div3.p:
The necessities of the war, in which we are engaged, demand the most careful consideration; and nothing should be left undone that is necessary to keep our regiments full, and ensure to our army the greatest efficiency.
In submitting what follows I am not moved by self conceit, but by a desire to contribute my mite, if haply it be a mite.

It is generally conceded that a protracted war cannot be efficiently prosecuted without regulars.
Volunteers for the war are regulars.
To induce men to enlist for the war a bounty of fifty dollars is paid; as a bounty — that is all right, and well enough as far as it goes, but does it go far enough? I think not, and I will give my reasons, such as they are, for my opinion.
Many patriotic men are poor, and have a mother, a wife, and children, or helpless brothers and sisters dependent upon them — and all these poor patriots possess is their personal effort; they live and sustain their loved ones by the sweat of their brows Such men cannot afford to go in the army during the war, as our affairs are now regulated, because, if they perish in battle, or by diseases and casualties incident to war, they will leave their families utterly destitute.--What should be done to obviate this difficulty?
It is only necessary for the present — till a better system can be matured — to let the pay, of such soldiers continue, if they perish in war, to their families — say, if it is a mother of the soldier, during her life — if it is his widow, during her life, or widowhood — if it be his orphans, till the youngest attain the age of sixteen--if his brothers and sisters till the youngest is old enough to be put to learn a trade, or to some honest way of making a living.
With this regulation by law, made at once, in addition to the $50 bounty--thousands, before the spring, would enroll their names for the war. This privilege should be allowed to those now in the service as well as to those who are out.

It would not interfere with the companies nor regiments now in the field.
All that is necessary is to get them enrolled, when they could be arranged into companies and proper officers assigned, and the day one service expired the other would begin, and no confusion take place, and our army would present the same compact form to our foes that it does now, and be far more efficient.
It may be objected that this arrangement would enhance the expenses of the war, and make our war debt ultimately more onerous.
Grant it, and what of it?
No one abhors more than I do wasteful and needless expenditure, and no one despises more than I do that "penny- wise and pound-foolish" economy that hesitates to meet all wise and proper expenditure of war.

This war we must fight, and more than that we must conquer.
It is not in our power to decline the combat, if we were craven enough to desire to do so, but fight we must. Upon this wager of battle all that is dear to man is suspended.
Win it, and the sun never shone upon so glorious and free, so rich and prosperous a people as we soon shall be. Lose it, and the soul sickens at the picture, our country ravaged, our homes destroyed, our altars defiled, our mothers, wives, sisters and daughters outraged, and we should go forth (despoiled of all that elevates and ennobles man and makes life tolerable) degraded and debased.
It is but the miser's trick, who chaffers with the under taker to cheapen his coffin, to withhold any expense that will really tend, however remotely, to victory, for with us it is indeed victory or death.
England forgets not the families of her soldiers, and England's example, in this regard, is well worthy of imitation.

Our volunteers have done nobly, and many of them seem to scorn the $50 bounty.
Very well, I rather like that, it shows their patriotism is still burning brightly; may it ever burn, and grow ever more brilliant, and be always as it now is, the glory of our nascent Confederacy.

There are those, however, who feel an equal ardor for their country who are too poor to carry their ardent feelings into action — unless they have assurance that their loved ones at home are safe from want.
The domestic affections are, as well as patriotism, manly and noble — and indeed he makes but a poor patriot whose heart is dead to this elevating and refining love.
It is easy for a man in easy circumstances to go forth to battle for his home and country, when he knows his loved ones will not suffer; but it is hard for a brave boy to go forth on a like errand, and leave a poor old mother in want at home.
The Confederacy must be her son and care for the beloved old mother.
I know of a noble old mother who has but two boys, she sent them both to battle, and was only sorry she did not have a dozen more to sent.
These dear old heroines must not be humiliated by depending upon private charity — they are the mothers of the Confederacy, and have made it what it is, God for ever bless them.

Let those who do not desire the bounty, nor need any after care of their families, volunteer as they did at first, and nobody will complain, but love them all the more for it. And it will be well for our rulers to beware how they lay their hands rudely upon the volunteer system.
We owe them everything.
What would have been our condition but for the noble enthusiasm of our brave young men, the generosity of the rich, and the devotion of our women?
Long, long ago, some Yankee would have lorded over every household.
Again I say, let our rulers bewares how they lay their hands rudely upon them.
They are our sons and brothers, and nobly have they vindicated their own and their country's honor.

Nobody cares how heavily the Legislature or Congress may bear upon the sleek, greasy, lazy loons who have been deaf to her country's call in the hour of danger.
Get them out any way, and for any length of time you please; nobody cares.

To the volunteer, hold out the lure of promotion for valor.
Napoleon the First understood that charm and conjured with it, and he was a mighty magician in the art of making heroes.
For a deed of more than ordinary daring, whether done by an officer or private he was sure of his reward.
The badge of the Legion of Honor put him in the way of promotion and made him famous.
In our army, all such cases should be reported at once to the President, and suitable notice taken of it. Beta.

div3.head: Headqr's of 8th Va. Reg't, near Centreville, Jan. 20th, 1862.
div3.p: all officers, non-commissioned officers, and soldiers, belonging to the 8th Virginia Regiment, who have not been detailed, by special order emanating from General Headquarters, and who are not actually disabled by sickness for duty, will immediately join this Regiment.

It is an outrage now, become too apparent, that whilst the brave and faithful are suffering all the hardships incident to camp life, the trifling and self-indulgent, are so derelict to their duty, as to absent themselves from their companies, thus throwing all of the work upon the few good soldiers who maintain their posts, to the scandal and disgrace of the fair name of the 8th Virginia Regiment, won on the fields of Manassas and Lees burg.

If this order is not promptly obeyed, I will in ten days, have handfills posted in every village in the country, offering a reward of thirty dollars for the apprehension of each deserter, and his delivery to the nearest military post, and I will so minutely describe each man, his appearance, character and habits, that the publication itself will be prove a severe penalty for his offence.
div3.closer:
Norborne Berkeley.

Hdqs.
Ordnance Dep't of Va., Richmond, January 11, 1862.
div3.p:
As there are yet a large number of Flint Lock Muskets distributed over this State, those having them, in large or small numbers, are again urgently requested to send them in, to my Address, that they may be altered and put in good order, ready for the use of the troops that will take the field next spring.
Each musket is of great value, as none can be bought, or made, in the State.
div3.closer:
Chas. Dimmock.
